node.title: Zombie cicadas, honey fungus and psychedelics: welcome to the wild world of fungi
node.alt: Picture of golden mushrooms clustered together on the forest floor.
node.description: The biologist says there's a lack of research into fungi despite more than 90 per cent of plants dependant on the micro-organisms to help them to extract nutrients.
node.content:
["Merlin Sheldrake describes fungi as something strange and peculiar.", "But it's also fascinating, which is why the study of some of the world's tiniest and largest organisms has consumed his life for almost three decades.", "The London-based biologist began taking an interest in fungi from the age of five. By the time he was a teenager, he was growing mushrooms and brewing medieval ales from bog myrtle in his bedroom.", "", "
Merlin Sheldrake says that without fungi, there would be no land plants.(Supplied:\u00a0Hanna-Katrina Jedrosz)
", "His love for fermenting went well beyond those four walls.", "When he was studying at Cambridge\u00a0University, he went scrumping and stole apples, said to be the\u00a0same variety that inspired\u00a0Sir Isaac Newton's law of gravity, from the botanic\u00a0gardens\u00a0to make natural yeast-fermented cider.", "\"Some likened the flavour [of the apples] to Newton's character in his later life. No one was going to eat the apples,\" Sheldrake says, of the legendary scientist's reportedly dour personality.\u00a0\u00a0", "\"But we took many of them, then pressed them\u00a0and made a cider, which was delicious to my surprise, \" he told ABC RN's Life Matters.", "Now he's\u00a0written a book on fungi called Entangled Life, which looks at how the micro-organisms\u00a0could help everyone\u00a0understand\u00a0our planet better.", "
What are fungi?
", "Until the 1960s, fungi were classified as\u00a0plants, but that's no longer the case. These eukaryotic organisms, which include mushrooms, yeasts and moulds, fall under their own kingdom, and have more in common with animals, Sheldrake says.", "\"Unlike plants which make their own food by eating light and carbon dioxide \u2026 fungi have to find food\u00a0in the world ready-made and digest it as we do too,\" he explains.", "One\u00a0fungus\u00a0he is particularly interested in is the honey fungus. It's a group of fungi that can grow expansively beneath the soil's surface and it's known to kill and devour trees by cutting off the flow of their sap.", "They can be vast \u2014 a honey fungus in Oregon is one of the largest known organisms in the world.", "\"That [honey fungus] spills over nearly 10 square kilometres and is somewhere between 2,000\u20138,000 years old,\" he says.", "And there are probably many other larger specimens that remain undescribed, he adds.", "Another fungus he's interested in is mushrooms, and he's not the only one. \u00a0", "\"It's funny you see in different cultures around the world a tendency to celebrate mushrooms or to fear them,\" Sheldrake says.", "\"Eastern European cultures tend to be really fond of them, and in Russia there are several common surnames which are the names of different species of mushroom, which is not something you find in English.\"", "
Zombie cicadas
", "Fungi can do a lot of things \u2014 different types of fungi\u00a0eat\u00a0rock, make\u00a0soil and digest\u00a0pollutants. It can induce visions, it produces food, it can make medicines\u00a0and it can even manipulate animal and insect behaviour.", "For instance, cicadas in North America are among the insects that have fallen victim to a fungus called massospora, which infects them\u00a0and can manipulate their behaviour.", "The fungus grows inside the cicadas and causes the backside of their bodies to disintegrate, Sheldrake explains.", "\"It pilots their flight, and meanwhile [it's] dropping spores out of their broken back ends,\" he says.", "\"The males go and try to mate with other cicadas to infect them with the spores.\"", "A team of US researchers, including Matt Kasson\u00a0who studied fungi at West Virginia University, analysed the bodies of infected cicadas to understand how this fungus is able to control the behaviour of the insect in such a precise way.", "They found a type of plant amphetamine in infected periodical cicadas \u2014\u00a0the insects that emerge from the soil after 13\u201317 years underground \u2014 and the presence of psilocybin in infected annual cicadas.", "\"And they found that the fungus was producing both an amphetamine and psilocybin, which was a big surprise, because psilocybin had not been found in a fungus of this type,\"\u00a0Sheldrake says.", "Their findings concluded that the fungus was somehow able to use these psychedelics and amphetamines to influence these behaviours in the cicadas, he adds.", "
Crucial life partners
", "Sheldrake\u00a0says there's a lack of research into fungi, despite more than 90 per cent of plants depending on the micro-organisms to help them extract nutrients. So he's determined to play his part.", "He's also working with an organisation called the Society for the Protection of Underground Networks (SPUN). The group is trying to map and protect the underground fungal networks of the world in such a way that they can optimise the carbon-storing ability of certain fungi.", "\"Fungi form crucial life partners with plants. In fact, they have a crucial role in the evolution of plants.\"", "He adds fungi played an important role in helping ancestors of plants out of the water and onto the land.", "\"So without fungi, there would be no land plants.\"\u00a0"]
